Hello, I am Gavin Hannon and today we're doing session seven assignment which is on the capital asset pricing model. And so what we have for the assignment is we have three companies and we're going to try and figure out their cost of equity and provide strategic recommendations for the cost of capital management. So we have three companies. One's a cloud tech software startup. It's got a 1.8 8 beta. Uh got company D is Regional Bank Corporation. It's got beta of 0.9 and company C's green energy utilities beta of.5. The market parameters we have is a risk-free rate of 4.5%. Uh market risk premium of 6% and expected S&P boundary return of 10.5%. Some market contexts to look at is Federal Reserve maintaining higher for longer rate stance. uh technology sector valuations compressed 30% from the peak and the flight to quality and economic is uncertain uncertainty. So

to define and discover our objective is basically to determine the cost of equity of the three companies and this will establish the minimum required rate of return for equity investors and we're going to use that to formulate a strate strategic recommendations on the cast cost capital management. So key constraint is obviously we are only relying on a single risk factor of beta and nothing else. Uh the analysis must use the provided market parameters fixing the key inputs despite the current volatile market contexts and the market context integr recommendations must strategically address the backup of rising interest rate environment and compressed technology evaluations. So to know that our project will be successful is if we accurately calculate the cost of equity. We the cost equity reflects the respective risk profiles data of the three companies and the analysis provides relevant actual strategic recommendations. So once we do all that we will know that we were successful. So to start is we have important information beta beta which is what what is beta? Beta. Beta measures a company's systematic risk which is the portion of risk that cannot be diversified away and is related to the overall market. If beta is greater than one, it's more volatile and than the market. If it's less than one, it is less volatile and if it's equal to one, it moves exactly with the market. So using those the explanation of beta differences across companies cloud tech has a high beta of 1.8 it's reflects how it's a high growth um software model and tech companies often see are seen as non-essential and more speculative. uh regional bank has a beta of 0.9 which is right around the the market so it's going to move with it and green energy has a 0.5 this is car very characteristic of the utility sector as it's a necessity so there's no really elasticity

so industry and business model impact on the systematic risk Cloud Tech's high beta stems directly from just being a software uh service and it has a high growth technology industry. The bank beta is close to the market because financial services are fundamental to the economy but it's specific risk keep it slightly above the average and the utility low beta is a classic example of just low systematic risk. So f another things you want to know is business versus financial risk. Business risk is the uncertainty inherent in a company's operations industry and this is measured by unlevered beta. So cloud tech is all all of its risk is business risk since there's the firm has no debt. Financial risk on the hand is additional risk introduced by using debt in the capital structure which is basically what banks do and green energy utilities do the same thing. So their fundamental business is much much lower than the cloud text. So next before um implementing we have represent we want to outline our what we plan on doing and so first let's calculate the cost effective calculations which we can actually just do by hand and this is what's shown here in the chart not the the the pivot chart and so you take the risk-free rate of 4.5 you add the beta and you times that by 6%. And so Cloud Tax Beta is 15.3%. And it's very above the market average. The Regional Bank Corp had a 9.9% uh um rate and that's slightly less sensitive to the market. So it means it's slightly less sensitive to the market swings. And Green Energy Utilities had a 7.5% of the capital asset uh calculation. and it's so it's low, it's more of a defensive and it's more stable. So now we have a security market lines construction and this basically is just going to show how the beta is related to the required return and we're going to use this to show the the risk return relationship with this chart. So as you can see a risk-free asset has um zero zero uh beta and that means it's very low uh low risk and you can see on the opposite end of it is the cloud tech obviously that has a high beta so it's going to have a much more higher risk return.

Next is the implement

which here. So my code that I created uh takes a step by step of what I want to assess and first is step one calculate the cost of equity. So, it's gonna take the beta the risk-free rate plus the uh the the beta times the market risk premium. And next step two is I want to provide strategic recommendations that I could impact on cloud tax beta and its cost of equity which is in stage step two and step three and four are going to um use things that I should also cons like I'm going to calculate things I should also consider when thinking about recommendations. So once we run the code we can see here that we have it they gave us the the cost of equity that I calculated earlier. So that's insane. And so basically before uh getting into it, we want to validate our our what we got or and so to validate I compared the betas to the industry averages which I used beta by sector and I pulled out the average of each. And for software it was 1.69 average which was it which is close to the 1.8 for the cloudte. The bank was a regional for was about 0.55. So a little lower than what um we have in our scenario and utilities is 39 which is roughly about what we have for our scenario. But basically uh the pro the proportions of each uh company is relevant to actually what is in real life like soft software industry is has a much higher beta than bank and that shows in our problem as well. So next we want is compare across the economic conditions. So ourly cloud tech is a premium over the average software beta and it's consistent with its high growth startup status. So investors demand much higher compensation for the additional idioyncratic risk and lack of profit profitability. And for the regional bank the beta is appropriate for a stable mature bank whose system risk is defined by its role as just financial intermediary

and green energy the low bit is expected for a defensive regulated utility confirming its position as a flight to quality asset. So now using um our code and some of the issues that might arise. So basic strategies for cloud tech to reduce the cost of equity for them. I would suggest reducing the operating leverage which this is a transition to a b business model with a higher proportion of variable costs related to fixed costs.

So this means like giving getting away from more of the the technology part and like leaning towards more of a safer um um company. And next is improve revenue, predictability and stability which is like secure longerterm enterprise contracts or move into less cyclical uh customer segments. This is predictable cash flows signal lower business risk to the market. Next is the strategic uh M&A and we want to acquire smaller stable firms who combine cash flow and risk power would smooth out the overall company volatility since it's so high for a um software software company. And basically another uh strategy would be to strengthen the financial health, improve your credit rating and establish a clear path and look for more profitability and reduce more bankruptcy risk and operational uncertainty. So what our code does is it also shows this like for each one if it's we want to reduce operating leverage our new beta would decrease and our new cost of equity would decrease and so forth and so on like each strategy it shows that like if you do this your beta would decrease and your new cost of equity would also um decrease. So next before like what else you want to make uh note of is um

the impact interest rate has on um this the cost of equity which so basically an increase in interest rate would increase by the same amount in your cost of equity and this show is shown on

um right here like if the interest rate increased by 1% your your 15.3% cost of equity would also increase by 1% to get to 16.3.

Next the other thing that has impact on uh cost effect is recession and this leads to a lower market rate risk premium. So investors become more uh more uh scared and they want to demand a higher return per unit risk which would increase the market rate premium. And this usually um increases cloud tax cost of equity but decreases uh green energy and the bank uh company. And this is seen seen right here where if the market rate premium went up to 8%. The beta for cloud tech would go up actually or they would all go up but except for the green energy utilities. They will decrease and their cost of equity would all inc all increase but by very little change for the green energy utilities and by a lot for the cloud tech.

So basically what our recommendations are is for cloud tech is to focus on the profitability gain less risk in the business in the in the business uh compare its beta and valuation metrics against similar profitable uh software companies and make sure you understand and make sure the company knows how its business model can withstand a high rate environment. So to now next is to reflect. It is important to note that this model um has its um has downside which is basically that uh investors assume that they can invest in a theoretically perfect market portfolio which the world is not perfect. So this perfect scenario doesn't make uh wouldn't really help them a whole lot. This also has where they assume all investors assume they have the same expectations for risk return and time horizon. And once again as I stated earlier it's only a single factor just beta and beta is calculated from historical which you can't really use like you can't expect that to actually happen in the future. Next, I want to compare the dividend discount model and to this model. And the dividend discount model is probably only good for firms like green energy because it has predictable growth where it's not good for the cloud s the cloud uh software company.

And all in all, I think the basically I just think the the CAPM model is really helpful for all investors to help see the relationship between the risk and expected return on an asset.

I'm also too looking into the arbitrage pricing theory or the AP which is a more general model that uses multiple macroeconomic factors instead of just the market return which again offers this deeper perspective on risk drivers and allows for a deeper understanding of the CAPM and how that affects um risk and return as a whole. So the root utilizes beta which is that pricing system risk which is the risk that cannot be eliminated through diversification and how that it is rewarded with a higher expected return for a higher beta which we'll dive into in the examples in just a moment. which is our startup, 15.3%, regional
bank, mature, which is 9.9%, green energy,
utility, 7.5%. The formula used is cost
of equity equals risk-free rate plus,
in parentheses together, beta times market
risk premium. So our risk-free rate is
4.5% and our market risk premium is 6%.
So here's our financial analysis using the
KISS method, which is to keep it simple and
stupid. So cost of equity and security market
line. With Cloud Tech, we find that 4.5
% plus 1.8 times 6% equals 15.3%, which gives

gives us 4.5 percent plus zero percent
times six percent which gives us 9.9 percent

percent plus zero four point five percent plus
point five percent times six percent equals
seven point five percent which gives us a

plus six percent equals ten point five
percent cloud tech is way up this line and
green energy is near the bottom so why are
the beta so different beta measures how much
a company's stock swings with the overall
market so cloud tech Our beta here is high.
Tech startups are speculative. Their success
depends heavily on the economy. In a boom,
they soar more than the market. In a bust,
they crash more than the market. This high
volatility equals high risk, which is a
high beta. Regional banks' beta is near 1.
Banks are the economy. Their performance is
tied directly to economic health, business
loans, and interest rates, just like the overall
market. It's slightly less volatile,
making it a bit safer than the average stock.
Green Energy's beta is very low.
Utilities are defensive stocks. People
pay their electric bills whether
the economy is good or bad. Their
profits are stable and often regulated.
This business is boring, which means
it's low risk. Gives us our low beta.
So,
how can Cloud Tech reduce its cost of capital?
Cloud Tech has 100 % equity structure
and a very high 5.3% cost of equity. To lower
its overall cost of capital it can do two
things one lowers beta make the business
boring it can secure long-term contracts such
as shifting from high growth speculation
to predictable multi -year contracts of big
customers annual recurring revenue stable
cash flow is less risky it can diversify it
can add products or services that are as
cyclical it can improve transparency clear
consistent communication with investors can
reduce uncertainty and surprise volatility
which can help lower beta over time and two
it can add debt change the capital structure
the trade-off right now it's weighted
average cost of capital whack it's just its
cost of equity 15.3 percent that is usually
cheaper than equity and the interest is tax
-deductible the cloud tech takes on some
debt such as a loan at 7% it can lower its
overall whack warning adding that makes the
equity part even riskier as our beta goes
up because debt holders get paid first you
have to find the right balance so what happens
in a recession. In a recession, investors
panic and flee to quality. What happens?
The market risk premium goes up. Investors
demand a higher reward for taking any risk.
That 6% MRP might jump up to 9%. The impact?
This pushes high beta stocks the most.
Let's assume the MRP jumps from 6% to 9
% and the risk rate stays at 4.5%. So in
conclusion, risky assets like cloud
tech become extremely undesirable in a
recession and their cost of capital explodes
making it very hard to raise money.
So is CAPM perfect? No. CAPM is
simple but it has big limitations.
Limitation 1. Only one factor. CAPM assumes
beta is the only risk that matters. This
is wrong. Other things like company size
or Venus value stock also affects returns.
Limit 2. Estimates their guesses.
The market risk premium 6% and beta 1
.8 are just estimates based on past
data. They are facts and can change.
Alternative, dividend discount model, DDM.
What is it? It's a stock price is the
sum of all its future dividends. How it
works? You can rearrange the formula to find
the cost of equity. Our cost of equity
would be next year's dividends divided by
current stock price plus dividend growth
rate. Once you use it, it's great for stable
dividend paying companies like the bank
or utility it's completely useless for
cloud tech which pays no dividend so here's

our calculations and rates that we have

the results show a clear link between risk

over green energy regional bank and cloud
tech why they're so much different and how
our recession impact of recession hits investors
panic and demand higher returns and this
would massively punish high beta stocks
like cloud tech whose cost of capital would
skyrocket while the low beta utility like
such as green energy would barely be affected
and going over our model limitations how
cap m is cap m is a simple useful tool but
it's not perfect it relies on estimates and
only looks at one risk factor beta other
models like the dividend discount model work
well for the banking utility bar totally
useless for cloud tech because it because it

Hello everyone my name is Alejandro Jervis and I will present my assignment 7. today I'll introduce the Capital Asset Pricing Model, or CAPM, and then walk through my Python implementation using the DRIVER method—Define, Reason, Inputs, Visualize, Example, Review. First, a quick CAPM overview: CAPM translates market risk into the required return that equity investors reasonably demand for a particular stock. The idea is compact: the required return equals a baseline "safe" rate plus extra compensation for bearing market risk, scaled by the stock's sensitivity to the market, which we call Beta tells us how much the stock tends to move when the market moves: a beta above 1 means the stock amplifies market swings and should command a higher required return; a beta below 1 dampens market swings and should command a lower return. On the Security Market Line, R_fis the intercept, the market risk premium is the slope, and beta is the x-axis; move right to a higher beta and the fair required return rises linearly. This matters because the CAPM output is exactly what we use as the cost of equity—the discount rate in DCFs and DDMs, the hurdle rate for projects, and a consistent yardstick to compare firms. It's powerful because it's simple, auditable, and comparable across companies; its limits are clear too: it prices only market risk and assumes reasonably stable inputs and a meaningful beta, so in practice we sanity-check inputs and, when needed, triangulate with alternative models.

Now I'll explain my Python script with DRIVER. (D—Define) The goal of my script is to compute the cost of equity for three companies with different risk profiles using CAPM, produce a clean table that's easy to paste into a write-up, and attach a one-line strategic implication for each firm so the numbers immediately translate into actions or expectations. (R—Reason) I structured it this way for transparency and reuse: by separating the assumptions, the company data, and the calculation, I can defend each assumption, show exactly how risk flows into the required return, and hand over an output that's presentation-ready without manual spreadsheet work. (I—Inputs) I explicitly set the CAPM components at the top of the script: a risk-free rate RISK_FREE_RATE = 0.035 (3.5%) and an expected market return EXPECTED_MARKET_RETURN = 0.105 (10.5%). From those, the code computes the market risk premium as 0.07 (7.0%). I print these three parameters first so the audience sees the assumptions before any results. Then I define three companies with their betas and short business contexts to make the risk feel concrete: CloudTech (Startup A) with β = 1.8 (high-growth SaaS, volatile), Regional Bank Corp (B) with β = 0.9 (defensive financials, less volatile than the market), and GreenEnergy Utilities (C) with β = 0.5 (regulated utility, very low systematic risk). (V—Visualize) Even without plotting, the code mirrors the Security Market Line logic. Conceptually, RISK_FREE_RATE is the intercept, MARKET_RISK_PREMIUM is the slope, and each firm's beta pins its x-position; the higher the beta, the further up the line we move to find the required return. (E—Example) The core calculation is a direct translation of CAPM:
required_return = RISK_FREE_RATE + beta * MARKET_RISK_PREMIUM.

With my inputs, the numbers come out as follows: for CloudTech (β=1.8), 3.5%+1.8×7.0%=16.1%; for Regional Bank (β=0.9), 3.5%+0.9×7.0%=9.8%; for GreenEnergy (β=0.5), 3.5%+0.5×7.0%=7.0%. Immediately after computing each required return, the script maps beta to a concise Strategic Implication via a simple rule set: β>1.5 is flagged as "extremely high cost of equity," which implies the firm must emphasize capital efficiency and a credible path to profitability; β between 1.0 and 1.5 is "high," so strong growth execution is required to justify valuation; β between 0.8 and 1.0 is "moderate," where efficiency and potentially dividends matter; and β below 0.8 is "low," suited to stable, long-duration investments. I collect the company name, beta, required return, and implication into a list of dictionaries, convert that into a pandas DataFrame with clear column headers—Company, Beta (Systematic Risk), Required Return (Cost of Equity), and Strategic Implication—format the returns as percentages for readability, and lift the column width limit so the implication text isn't truncated. The script then prints a professional, index-free table that's easy to drop into a memo. Finally, it prints a short summary that makes the ranking explicit—r_A>r_B>r_C—and notes that these CAPM-derived rates are ready to plug directly into DDM, DCF, and other present-value models. (R—Review) What I like about this approach is that it's auditable (assumptions are explicit), comparable (same slope/intercept across firms), and decision-oriented (each number is paired with a plain-English implication). The model's caveats are also transparent: CAPM prices only market risk, inputs like R_fand E[R_m]should be chosen thoughtfully, and beta itself can vary with estimation windows and leverage changes. If I were extending this, I would add a small sensitivity band around the risk-free rate and the market risk premium to show best/base/worst required returns, and optionally plot a simple Security Market Line with the three firms labeled to make the geometry visible. But as presented, the script cleanly demonstrates the CAPM workflow end-to-end: Define the objective, Reason about the structure, specify Inputs, Visualize the logic of the SML, run the Example that ties numbers to strategy, and Review strengths, limits, and next steps—leaving us with clear, defensible costs of equity for three distinct risk profiles.. In conclusion the work went very well and once again its demonstrated how AI can be a great tool for financial decisions.

Hello, my name is Kwon Kim, and I am in the Management 310 section. And today I'll be presenting my session seven assignment where I am working for a venture capital firm as an analyst, and I'm looking to use CAPM or the Capital Asset Pricing Model Calculator, or using CAPM in order to estimate the return on equity or the cost of equities for different companies. And I'm gonna start by defining a few key terms that we'll be using today and what that implies for our goals. And so, first, the Capital Asset Pricing Model, or CAPM, is a model that estimates the expected risk or cost of equity for an investment based on its systematic risk.

And so, it uses concepts like the cost of equity or the return required by equity investors to compensate for the risk of owning shares in a firm instead of risk-free securities. It represents the firm's equity's hurdle rate or what needs to be overlooked or achieved in order to make that investment. It also has the concept of a risk-free rate, which is the return on an investment with zero default risk. It's typically the yield on a 10-year US Treasury bond. So in this scenario, we said about 4%, and it sets the baseline for required return since that's essentially almost an opportunity cost that they could be investing in otherwise if they weren't investing in this company. Next, we'll be looking at the market risk premium, which is the extra return that investors demand for taking on the average market risk versus holding a risk-free asset.

And all those factors together are going to give you the, are going to be in the model of the CAPM, which has the features of the risk-free rate. And you're going to be adding a function of the market risk premium and the expected market return. You'll see a graph that shows this visually later. Some things that affect a company's ability to make these returns and affect their cost of equity are things like their beta, which is essentially a measure of a stock's sensitivity to overall market movements. So if you have a company with a beta of one, it means that it moves along with the market. And so it's going to have similar returns as to if you were just invested in like general index funds.

And then if it's more than one, it's going to be more volatile. And so you're going to have higher systematic risk with more ups and with higher ups and very lower downs. And then if it's less than one, it's going to be less volatile than the market with the lower systematic risk. Systematic risk is a non-diversifiable risk tied to overall market movements such as interest rates, inflation, recessions. You can't diversify it away like we did in our previous assignment where we looked at different stock portfolios and saw how diversifying different portfolios can reduce that risk. Systematic risk is inherent, and you can't just try different combinations to get it away. And then the graphical representation of CAPM is known as a security market line.

And it shows that relationship between expected returns on the Y-axis and beta on the X-axis. The slope is equal to the market risk premium, and assets above the SML are undervalued, meaning that they are returning or offering higher returns for their risk. And then, those below are under overvalued, meaning that you are not receiving as much return as you should for the amount of risk that you are taking on. And so I'm going to go over to our tool. Today, I made a website with Repl. it, and essentially I had to make a new account for this since I used up my free ones already. But essentially, this is a capital asset pricing model that allows you to enter different parameters about a company and allows you to see a visual representation of that.

And so first, if I go into number of companies to analyze, for our purposes today, if I look at the session seven assignment, our companies, we have three of them. Company A is a cloud tech software startup. And then we have a bank and then green energy utilities company. And some differentiating factors between these three companies are their beta, the capital structure, the industry, and the stage that they're in. We have a startup here. It is high growth, but obviously, earlier companies are going to have more risk and more volatility. And so that's something that's going to factor into the returns or the risks that you're taking for that. And then this is the general market that you're working with. So the risk-free rate, which is that kind of hurdle that you need to get over, is at 4.

5%. The market risk premium is going to be 6% or the extra that you're demanding because of the risks that you're taking. And then the returns that you could get with the S&P are going to be 10. 5%. And then here's the market context that the Federal Reserve is maintaining a higher-for-longer rate stance and that the technology sector valuations are compressed 30% from peak. There's also a flight to quality amid economic uncertainty. And so those are the context of the market, their parameters, and then the three companies that we're looking at, all with different betas. As expected, the software startup is going to have a higher beta, meaning it's more volatile. And then we have a pretty similar-to-market beta, which is 0. 9 at the bank.

And then a very low volatility, probably very little returns, or lower than usual returns, is going to be the utilities. And so if we enter into our design here, let's start with the first company. I'm just going to call this company A and then SAS, since it is a software-as-a-service startup. And then I believe the beta was 1.8. And then the capital structure is going to be 100% equity financed, which is quite, it seems quite aggressive. And then it's going to be technology and it's going to be a startup. So, as suggested, because Repl. it is an AI tool, it has the range for a technology startup; it's going to have already a set or suggested beta of 1. 5 to 2.

The way they calculated that is taking that first hurdle, that risk-free rate is going to be 4. 5%; then you're going to multiply that beta by the market risk premium, and that's going to get you the 15. 3. So you can see because we're adding here, if we had a higher beta, then the cost of equity would be higher, and then also if we had a higher hurdle rate, that would be 4. 5% right now, or like that US bond return, that would be higher. It also creates this graph for you. And so, I described before, this is your security market line, and so anything under that is going to be undervalued, and then, I mean, overvalued, and then anything above is going to be undervalued.

And so, here you can see, let's say you're like somewhere down here, taking on a lot of risk for little returns. Well, if you're up here, you're taking on an appropriate amount of risk for an appropriate amount of returns or even more. If you look at company A, which is that SaaS startup, you are on that line, and so you're going to be at 1. 8 beta right here, and then the cost of equity is going to be 15. 3. And if that means that if we're doing like a sensitivity analysis, it means that based on the risk-free rate and the market risk premium, that you are going to have a higher risk than market average. And this is like another feature that I added here.

Let's say we also want to change the environment, the market environment that it's in at that moment. We can change the risk-free rate, the market risk premium, as well as the expected S&P returns. Now I'm going to be comparing all three companies together. So we have company 1, 2, and 3. And so we already have company A, now we have company B, and that's going to be the bank. The beta was 0. 9. The capital structure is going to be very moderate. And then the industry is going to be in financial services. And this is going to be a, I believe it was mature. Yes, it's going to be mature. All right, if it's mature, it looks like the beta for this is actually lower than what mature companies typically see.

But the cost of equity here is, as expected, going to be lower since you do have that lower beta here. So there's that, and I'll show all three together. Company C is the utilities. And this one had a beta of 0. 5. This was a conservative capital structure. And then the industry is going to be in energy. And then this is going to be, I wouldn't say it's in decline, or I would say it's in decline since it does have predictable cash flows. It's no longer growing. Okay, so if we look at company three, we can see that this has the lowest cost of equity. And we can see those comparisons with company B, company C, and A. So overall, that beta volatility is going to be the biggest factor in that cost of equity.

And so if you think about the idea of cost of capital, it's a very accounting-heavy idea of a managerial accounting, where you're looking at whether or not you should look into an investment. You're looking at the minimum rate of return that a company must earn in order to satisfy its investors. And for all equity firms, the cost of capital is going to equal that cost of equity. So it's going to be that hurdle or that minimum point that you need to meet. And a capital structure is going to be the mix of debt and equity financing a firm uses. And so more debt means that you have a lot of financial risk or leverage. And 100% equity means that you have no leverage. You have a lower default risk and higher dilution risk.

If you look at a high-growth startup, a firm with rapid revenue expansion and high uncertainty is going to have usually like pretty negative cash flows, but with a large potential upside. And if we look at company A right here, we can see that where the cost of capital is very high or the cost of equity, which are very similar concepts, or they tend to be representing similar things, is going to be high as a high-growth startup. And then if we look at the fact that the technology market is in compression right now, decline in market multiples and private equity is going to be due to higher discount rates or weaker investment appetite for risk. And it's very common during those tech bubbles or rate hikes. And so that's why we have that 30% compression there.

And then, if we look down here to a sensitivity analysis for each company, here, what that's basically saying is how changes in input assumptions are going to affect the cost of output. So, like the beta is mainly like what we're looking at, or like the risk-free rate, the market premium. And then something that we also want to look at is like a recession scenario, which we're going to see where the market returns fall and investor risk aversion increases for high beta assets. And so if you think about during a recession, you're going to really want like those non-risky investments, and you're also going to have a lower S&P 500 return, which means if the overall market is not moving well, or it's in like a downward slope trend, that volatility is just going to get higher in comparison, which means the beta is just gonna be extremely high during recessions, especially for like those high-growth startups, which makes them very unappealing to investors.

And so some ways that companies can combat this is by having operational de-risking. And so those are actions that make earnings more stable: that's recurring revenue models, long-term contracts, or diversifying customers in order to reduce beta. And then also having really good investor communication. So, being transparent with your disclosure and having a predictable strategy can reduce perceived risk, but that's going to really be important during something like a recession. And so today we implemented the driver framework with my equity CAPM assignment, where I created a website that can have parameters that you input, such as the number of companies to analyze, the beta capital structure, and the industry, which all contribute to a suggested beta range that the website will give you.

And then once you enter that, it will use the market calculation for the cost of equity, which is going to be the risk-free rate plus the multiplication of the beta and the market risk premium. And that's going to give you the cost of equity. Then it takes all the companies that you inputted that information for, and it allows you to graph it. If I wanted to change these to indicate something like a recession, then that would also go ahead and change the context. And then if you're looking at like the risk-free rate, then that's going to be lower if you're in a recession. So that'd be like 2. 5, and that's going to also change. And so your cost of equity is going to be a little lower. But yes, or I guess if you're in a recession, it'd be higher. But regardless, here you can see those differences in the sensitivity analysis.

Answer:
I actually really liked this one. I feel like I, oh my goodness, so far have a really good understanding on the capital asset pricing model and the cost of equity. So we'll just jump right into session seven with our risk profile analysis. 

The core of this analysis is understanding systematic risk measured by beta, which is this symbol right here. Beta reflects how sensitive a company's stock return is to movements in the overall market. So this first little chart here, some of it is given to us, some of it I just wanted to dive in deeper. 

So we're given each company A, B, and C, their different beta levels, their risk profiles. So starting with cloud tech, they have a beta of 1.8 and they are considered an aggressive or high risk profile, which means that they have a high operational leverage. They have exposure to cyclical tech spending and they have rapid growth, but uncertain and no historic stability. 

Looking at company B, regional bank core, they have a beta of 0.9, so that would be like a defensive or pretty moderate risk. So they're also cyclical, sensitive to economic growth and interest rates, stuff like that, but they're more diversified operations and regulatory oversight than just pure tech. And lastly, looking at company C, they have a beta of 0.5, which is a very low risk profile.

They are highly regulated industry and essential service, such as like electricity, water, stuff like that, and very stable and predictable cash flows. So they are less sensitive to economic cycles. And we're going to jump into that here. 

The difference in data is given by the company's underlying business models and operating leverage. So for example, looking at cloud tech again, which had a high beta of 0.8, they are a software startup, which is inherently non-essential and revenues are tied to discretionary corporate IT spending. So in an economic downturn, this spending is quickly cut, leading to large swings in the stock's return relative to the where, if we look at green energy, which had that low beta, that is a utility service, which is absolutely a necessity. 

So demand and pricing are stable due to regulation, making its returns largely insulated from the overall economic cycle. Next step of the driver framework represents the security market line or SML. The security market line graphically represents the relationship between systematic risk, which is that beta, and the required return. 

The equation for the SML is the capital asset pricing model formula, which is this roughly formula right here. RF, the last chunk of the formula, is the market risk, the premium, and the MIP, which is 6%. And looking at our different companies, we know that cloud tech company A sits high on the SML, indicating a high required return for its high risk. 

Company B sits slightly below the market which is a beta of 1, and I believe that regional bank had a beta of 0.9. That reflects moderate risk of return. And then company C sits low on the SML, offering a lower required return for low risk, which we did talk about a little bit before with their risk profiles. Next step is implementing the cost of equity calculation. 

The cost of equity, which is the E, R, and I, is the required return calculated again using that formula right here, the capital asset pricing model. What did I just say? The capital asset pricing model, excuse me. And here you can see the calculations played out. 

So again, we're given the company, we're given the beta, we're given the risk-free rate, the MRP, and then finally we can plug in these numbers to the CAPM formula, and so we get cloud tech has 15.3% cost of equity, regional bank has 9.9% cost of equity, and clean energy has 7.5% of cost of equity. So, and then here's me just summarizing the calculations found. Next, we're going to validate using pure context and lowering cost of capital. 

So, my idea to provide context on small tech is spot on. Cloud tech's 15.3% cost of equity is a minimum hurdle rate for the venture capital firm. So, looking into this a bit more, cloud tech is a pre-IPO, like a unicorn, like Palantir, or an early stage company, like a small YC startup. 

These smaller firms have significant unsystematic risk. So, for example, a key person risk, failure of a single product, that the CAPM does not capture. So, the actual required return, given the context of small tech valuations have compressed 30%, the actual required return for cloud tech for a VC firm would likely be much higher, like 20 to 30%, than the CAPM suggests to account for liquidity risk and the high probability of failure. 

Looking at cloud tech's path to lowering cost of capital, cloud tech is 100% equity financed. So, its cost of capital is equal to its cost of equity, 15.3% that we found. To lower the weighted average cost of capital, WACC, or I like to say WACC, cloud tech could lower its beta. 

How could they do this? Well, diversify revenue, expand into more stable business lines or geographical markets. Another option to lower its beta is to reduce operating leverage, increase size and maturity. To do this, outsource non-core functions or shift from fixed cost to variable cost structures, simply reach a more stable size and demonstrate predictable cash flow over time. 

That would naturally lower your beta. Another thing that they could do to lower the WACC is to introduce debt financing, the optimal capital structure. Debt is usually cheaper than equity, lower required return and tax deductibility of interest payments. 

So, by adding an optimal level of debt, cloud tech could lower its weighted average cost of capital. Next step is evolve, impact of a recession in higher for longer rates. So, answering this next question, what would happen if there was a recession? The Fed's signal and the prospect of a recession fundamentally impact the inputs to the CAPM and the company's business risk, of course.

So, looking at this chart here, we have what would happen if the rates higher for longer and then the recession and tech valuation compression. So, the impact on RF and the MRP, they would increase and the impact on beta and the ERI, the entire SML would shift up. There's a required return for all companies, required return for all companies increases. 

Looking at cloud tech, we originally saw that their beta was 1.8. So, the recession causes a highly cyclical revenue to crash. So, the beta and the ERI would increase significantly. Looking at the mutual bank, had a beta of 0.9, increased loan defaults and lower lending. 

So, the beta and the ERI would increase moderately. And then for green energy, which had the beta of 0.5, the essential service remains stable. So, the beta and the security market line would be least affected, potentially only due to higher RF. 

So, the most sensitive is cloud tech, whose required return would spike due to both a higher risk-free rate and increased systematic systemic risk, which is a higher beta in a downturn. Now, reflecting on CAPM's utility and limitations, it provides a clear quantifiable link between a company's non-diversifiable risk, the beta, and its required return. It is a simple first-order approximation in the standard industry tool, making it easy to communicate and compare. 

It confirms the higher systemic risk demands a higher return, which is clearly illustrated by the 15.3% for cloud tech versus that 7.5% for green energy. Now, what it does miss, especially for startup businesses, is an unsystematic risk. It only accounts for systematic risks. 

For a single product startup like cloud tech, it misses the risk of failure, key person dependency, and lack of liquidity, which is what that small tech context provided. It also misses liquidity risks. It assumes that assets are easily traded, which is not true for a private company or illiquid startup investments. 

And lastly, model inputs. The calculation is highly sensitive to the inputs, particularly the long-term estimate of the beta and the MRP.

Right. This is my session seven assignment for management 310. Uh firstly, I'll be defining the problem that we have for this assignment. Determine the cost of equity for three companies with varying risk profiles using the capital asset pricing model. As an analyst for a venture capital firm, you must calculate required returns for investment evaluation and provide strategic recommendations for cost of capital management. The analysis occurs in a rising interest rate environment with compressed technology valuations. So all the data that we have are for these three companies. We have the beta uh which is 1.8 for cloud tech. Capital S structure is 100% equity financed industry is SAS stage high growth startup complete competing with est established firms so this is the all the data we have uh we'll be using beta mainly which is basically the risk of investing in a company uh but I'll explain it later when we go to my code uh company B the beta is 0.9 capital structure is traditional banking operations industries Financial services stage is mature and stable but slow growth. Company C green energy utilities beta 0.5 capital structure is regulated utility industry utilities stage is mature with predictable cash flows. Other market parameters that we have is risk rate 10-year Treasury is 4.5%, market risk premium is 6%, expected S&P 500 return is 10.5%. The context for this situation we have is Federal Reserve maintaining higher for longer rate stance. Technology sector valuations compressed 30% from peak and flight to quality and amid economic uncertaintity. These are the questions that we need to answer after analyzing all the data we have. We need to calculate cost of equity for each company using CAPM formula or method. So first what is CAPM? I'll explain this first before going to my code. So if you see here we'll be using this formula even in my code to calculate the CAPM for all the three companies that we have. So capital asset pricing model in this concept what we basically get is what is the expected return if we invest or buy a company's equity. So this formula is basically the expected return will be equal to the risk-free rate plus the beta. Beta is basically the risk that is involved in investing that company uh multiplied by expected return on market portfolio minus the market risk premium. So this is the formula that we'll be using today uh to answer all your questions. Now so go back to my assignment.

First we'll calculate cost of equity for each company using CPM. Explain data differences across industries and business models. Analyze strategies for cloud tech to reduce cost of capital. Assess recession impact on required returns. Compare CAPM estimates to alternate value alternate value valuation approaches. So to answer all this, I'll first go to the code and I'll explain my code first. It it uses all of my input data that we already had in the question. These are basically the betas or the risk involved in investing all of these three companies. Then it uses uh and creates a function u basically the formula that I just explained. Then we calculate the cost of the equity. Then we visualize it. And this code helps me make a a basically a graph in which I'll be able to easily uh explain to you how how the CAPM comes out to be of these three different companies. So we'll visualize that. Okay. So this is the part that I'll be answering later. So I'll just like run the code and go to what it help. Okay. So this is the first company cloud tech beta 1.58 cost of equity is 15.3%. Regional bank operation beta risk is 0.9% and the cost of equity is 9.9%. Green energy utilities beta is 0.5 cost of equity 7.5%. This is the graph uh that I was talking about. This basically shows us if we buy equity in green energy utilities the risk is this much and the return is this much. If we invest in regional bank corporation the beta the risk is this much and the expected return is this much. But if we uh invest or buy equity of cloud tech the risk is really high which is like around 1.75 but even the expected rate is high. So what this tells us if you use this method the more the risk or beta the higher are the expected rate of returns.

Now we'll go to the next question. Explain beta differences across industries and business models. Okay to answer this I wish this. Okay. Uh so higher beta is equal to company's return move more than the market. Lower beta is more stable returns. So basically beta is the risk that is involved in investing a company. Taking example of cloud tech they have high beta due to revenue uncertaintity, valuation volatility and fast changing customer behavior. These are the reasons why investing in cloud tech might be risky and we can obviously see this in this graph that higher the rate of return higher the beta is equal to higher the expected rate of return. Other factors might be uh utilities have very low beta but they provide essential services with long-term contracts and steady cash flow. So investing in those kind of business or other companies would be basically a safer option. You go to the next question. Analyze strategies for cloud tech to reduce cost of capital. Cost of capital as we see cloud tech had the highest. So to reduce that some of the few strategies that might work over here is increasing recurring revenue through long long-term subscription contacts that is as it is a SAS uh business uh improving customer retention and reduce churn to stabilize cash flows. Uh lower debt levels to reduce perceived financial risk. I diversify customer base to avoid dependence on a few large clients and improve investor transparency while reporting unit economics, customer metrics and profitability timeline. So these are the methods that would help cloud tech or any other SAS uh business to reduce cost of capital. Now if you see the recession impact on required returns in recession risk premium increases because investor demand more return for uncertaintity beta firms are effective most cost of equity rises faster this I'll explain using my code as in that graph also we can see so if you even take an example if the risk premium increases from 6 to 8% cloud tech required return increases significantly because higher risk is equal to higher rate of returns. Higher required returns makes fundraising harder and decreases company valuation. So I'll explain this using my code. Now

if we see over here calculating the cost of equity in this formula it runs uh it runs a for loop which will help us uh it takes that example of increasing the risk of return from 6% to 10%. And if we run this code, we'll be able to see over here if the scenario is normal and our beta are the same, the cost of equity is 15.3 for cloudtech, 9.9 regional bank corporation, 7.5 for green energy. But if there is recession and if we take the example of increasing the premium from 6% to 8% we can see how much the cost of equity increases because the risk is eventually higher at the time of recession. So we can see cloudtech the cost of equity increased from 15.3 to 18.9. Regional bank corporation the cost of equity increased from 9.9 to 11.7. green energy utilities 7.5 to 8.5 we can see at the time of recession the cost of equity increases eventually because of the risk involved at the time of recession

to answer the last question

compare capm estimates to alternate value valuation approaches. So if you compare uh CPM to other valuation approaches, CPM estimated estimates required return using beta which is the risk market risk and it it is pretty simple and it is widely majorly used in the real world. If you use the dividend discount model, it is for mature companies and dividend paying companies. So companies with IPOs uh in which the local people or the public can invest. So dividend discount model can be helpful for them. And other third one is multiffactor models. Uh these are the companies that wants to add size, value, momentum factors for better accuracy for their valuation. So this was the answer to the last question. uh to conclude uh the CPM PMA model or the method that we used here is in the graph this depicts uh that pretty clearly as the beta was higher for cloudtech the expected return was also higher but the cost of equity was also the highest for regional bank the beta was lower than cloudtech so the expected rate was way lower than uh cloudtech and the cost of equity was also lower if you compare it to cloud And finally, as the beta or the risk was the lowest for green energy utilities, the expected return was the lowest and the cost of equity was also the lowest. So this is what basically CPM uh approach helps us to get to. Thank you.

Answer:
Hello, my name is Anthony Kwon, and I'll walk through my CAPM and cost of equity analysis using the DRIVER framework.

First, in the Define stage, the goal of this project is to estimate the cost of equity for three companies with different risk levels using the Capital Asset Pricing Model. The three companies are CloudTech, a high-growth SaaS startup; Regional Bank Corp, a mature financial institution; and GreenEnergy Utilities, a stable regulated utility. I want to understand how their betas drive required returns, how economic conditions affect cost of capital, and what strategies CloudTech can use to lower its cost of equity.

The key market assumptions are a 4.5 percent risk-free rate, a 6 percent market risk premium, and an expected market return of 10.5 percent. CloudTech's beta is 1.8, Regional Bank's is 0.9, and GreenEnergy's is 0.5. The analysis takes place in a high-interest-rate environment, where tech valuations are down about 30 percent and investors are shifting toward safer assets.

Next is the Represent stage. My plan was to apply the CAPM formula, calculate the required return for each firm, visualize the Security Market Line, and interpret how beta affects expected return. Then I would validate results by comparing them with industry averages and explore strategies for CloudTech to manage its capital cost.

The CAPM formula is simple: required return equals the risk-free rate plus beta times the market risk premium. Using that, CloudTech's cost of equity is 15.3 percent, Regional Bank's is 9.9 percent, and GreenEnergy's is 7.5 percent. These results make intuitive sense — the higher the beta, the higher the expected return investors demand for taking on more risk.

In the Implement stage, I automated the calculation in Python and generated a Security Market Line. The graph shows a clear upward slope: as beta increases, so does required return. CloudTech appears at the top of the line, reflecting its high market sensitivity and growth volatility. GreenEnergy sits near the lower end, consistent with its defensive, low-risk nature.

Then comes the Validate stage. I compared my results to industry averages, and they match closely. Technology firms typically show betas between 1.6 and 2.0, banks around 0.9, and utilities near 0.5. This confirms that the model is consistent with real-world expectations. I also verified that shifts in the risk-free rate move the entire line up or down, and that beta correctly captures systematic risk differences.

In the Evolve stage, I considered how CloudTech could reduce its cost of equity. It can stabilize cash flows through recurring subscription contracts, diversify its customer base, form partnerships to improve credibility, and introduce moderate leverage since it is currently 100 percent equity-financed. Better investor communication can also lower perceived risk.

I ran a short sensitivity test: if the risk-free rate or market risk premium rises by one percent, CloudTech's cost of equity could increase by about 1.8 percent, showing that high-beta firms are more sensitive to market changes. In a recession, risk premiums would likely rise, pushing up required returns for all firms.

Finally, in the Reflect stage, I learned that CAPM, while simple, captures essential insights about the trade-off between risk and return. Beta provides a measurable link between market volatility and investor expectations. At the same time, CAPM has limitations — it doesn't include size, value, or firm-specific factors — so models like Fama-French or the Dividend Discount Model can complement it.

Overall, this project showed me how combining finance theory with technology makes analysis more transparent and efficient. Python automation helped visualize results instantly and test different scenarios. Using the DRIVER framework kept my work organized, from defining the problem to drawing conclusions.

In summary, CAPM helps quantify how much return investors require for bearing risk. CloudTech's high beta explains its higher cost of equity, while utilities and banks earn lower returns for lower risk. Understanding this relationship helps both investors and managers make smarter financial decisions.

Answer:
Hi everyone, my name is Jamie Lee, and this is my Section 6 and 7 CAPM and Cost of Equity analysis project.

For this project, I acted as an analyst for a venture capital firm evaluating three companies with completely different risk profiles — a high-growth software startup called CloudTech, a mature regional bank, and a regulated utility company called Green Energy.

The goal was to use the Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM) to calculate each company's cost of equity and understand how risk and market conditions affect investor return expectations.

I built everything in Python using Google Colab and followed the DRIVER framework step-by-step. Starting with the Define and Discover stage, I set up the context: we're currently in a "higher-for-longer" interest rate environment where rates remain elevated and tech valuations have fallen by about 30% from their peaks. Each company faces different levels of systematic risk.

CloudTech has a high beta of 1.8 since it's a fast-moving software services startup that's very sensitive to market swings. The regional bank's beta is around 0.9, close to the market average, while the utility company has a beta of 0.5, reflecting its stability and regulation.

My goal was to calculate each company's required return using CAPM, understand why these betas differ, and explore what CloudTech could do to reduce its cost of capital even though it's a riskier growth-oriented company.

In the Represent stage, I planned my workflow and outlined the CAPM formula — required return equals the risk-free rate plus beta times the market risk premium. I then mapped out each coding step like a blueprint, so I knew exactly what the final outputs would look like.

I defined the market parameters, computed each company's cost of equity, plotted the Security Market Line, and then tested how sensitive these costs were to changes in interest rates and the market risk premium.

Moving into the Implement stage, I coded the CAPM equation into a simple Python function using Pandas and Matplotlib to automate the calculations and visualizations. Running the first section printed the baseline CAPM results: CloudTech's cost of equity came out to around 15.3%, which makes sense — higher beta means higher expected return.

I then plotted the Security Market Line, showing beta on the x-axis and expected return on the y-axis. The line starts at the 4.5% risk-free rate and slopes upward by 6%, the market risk premium. I placed the three companies on the line so you can see how each one compares in terms of risk and return.

In the Validate stage, I confirmed everything behaved as expected. The slope matched the market risk premium, the intercept equaled the risk-free rate, and all three companies fell along the linear relationship — with CloudTech showing the highest required return and Green Energy the lowest.

In the Evolve stage, I expanded the analysis with sensitivity and scenario testing. I examined how changes in the risk-free rate (from 3% to 6%) impacted required returns — all three companies' costs rose in parallel, but CloudTech moved the most because of its higher beta.

I then tested different market risk premiums, which showed again that CloudTech's cost of equity is much more sensitive than the others, demonstrating how fragile high-growth valuations can be when investor sentiment shifts.

Finally, I modeled three macroeconomic scenarios: base case, mild recession, and severe recession. CloudTech's cost of equity rose from about 15.3% in the base case to 17.7% in a mild recession and over 21% in a severe downturn. The bank and utility also rose, but much less sharply — showing how betas expand during stress periods and how macro conditions heavily influence required returns.

In the Insights section, I explained why the betas differ. CloudTech's high beta comes from high operating leverage, volatile demand, and its dependence on investor sentiment. The bank's beta is close to one since its performance follows economic and interest rate cycles. The utility's low beta reflects stable, regulated cash flows and essential demand.

To reduce its cost of equity, CloudTech needs to make its revenue more predictable — things like locking in multi-year contracts, improving customer retention, diversifying its client base, and clearly communicating its path to profitability. Essentially, anything that de-risks its business model will compress its beta.

I also touched on CAPM's limits — it assumes efficient markets and that only systematic risk is priced, which isn't always true in reality. Models like the Dividend Discount Model or Fama-French Multi-Factor Model can capture other effects like size or value. Still, CAPM provides a great foundation for understanding the relationship between risk and return.

In the Reflect stage, running this analysis helped me connect financial theory with real-world strategy. Seeing how a company's beta directly impacts its cost of equity made the concept tangible. What stood out most was how sensitive CloudTech's required return is to even small market changes — reinforcing that while companies can't control interest rates or risk premiums, they can control transparency and predictability with investors.

If I were advising a company like CloudTech, I'd focus on improving unit economics, cash flow stability, and investor communication — because those factors actually move the needle on perceived risk.

Overall, this project showed me that CAPM isn't just a formula — it's a way to think about risk, valuation, and strategy together.

Answer: Hi, I'm Yanxi Liu. This is my Session 7 Assignment. The goal of this analysis was to understand how risk, interest rates, and market conditions shape investors' required returns, and to propose practical strategies for managing the cost of capital—especially in an environment where interest rates remain elevated and technology valuations are compressed. I followed the DRIVER format. In the Define and Discover stage, I began by clearly identifying the analytical objective. As an analyst working for a venture capital firm, my task was to estimate the cost of equity for three firms—CloudTech, Regional Bank Corporation, and GreenEnergy Utilities—each operating under very different risk profiles. The analysis would then inform strategic investment recommendations and cost of capital management approaches. The broader context is what economists call a "higher-for-longer" rate environment. The Federal Reserve is maintaining high interest rates to control inflation, while equity valuations, especially in the technology sector, have fallen about thirty percent from their peaks. Investors are increasingly showing a preference for safer, more predictable assets. These macroeconomic conditions directly affect how risk is priced in the market and, therefore, how companies must think about their cost of capital. I formulated five guiding questions to structure my work. First, what is the cost of equity for each company based on their exposure to market risk, or beta? Second, how do industry differences and business models explain variations in beta values? Third, how can CloudTech—a high-growth software startup—reduce its cost of capital in a volatile environment? Fourth, how would a recession or a shift in interest rates alter required returns and investor behavior? And finally, how does CAPM compare with alternative valuation frameworks when assessing the cost of equity? The market parameters I used are based on the following assumptions: a ten-year Treasury yield of four point five percent as the risk-free rate, a six percent market risk premium, and an expected S&P 500 return of ten point five percent. These parameters reflect current economic conditions and are consistent with a cautious, risk-sensitive investment climate. In the Represent stage, I translated the business question into a structured analytical model using the CAPM formula. The model states that the cost of equity equals the risk-free rate plus the company's beta multiplied by the market risk premium. This model links an asset's expected return directly to its exposure to systematic market risk. I then defined the three companies and their characteristics. CloudTech is a software-as-a-service startup, entirely equity-financed, operating in a highly competitive and fast-changing environment. Its beta is one point eight, indicating that its returns move much more aggressively than the overall market. Regional Bank Corporation represents a mature, stable financial institution with a traditional mix of deposits and loans. Its beta is zero point nine, roughly in line with moderate economic sensitivity. Finally, GreenEnergy Utilities is a regulated utility provider with predictable cash flows and limited exposure to market fluctuations. Its beta is only zero point five, reflecting its defensive and low-risk nature. At this stage, I also designed a conceptual workflow to guide the analysis: define the problem, model the CAPM framework, compute and visualize the results, test their realism, simulate different macroeconomic scenarios, and finally, reflect on the model's strengths and limitations. Moving into the Implement stage, I performed the CAPM calculations using Python. Using the formula and the parameters described earlier, I computed the cost of equity for each company. The results were clear and economically consistent. For CloudTech, with a beta of one point eight, the cost of equity is fifteen point three percent. This means investors require a fifteen percent return to compensate for the company's higher volatility and market sensitivity. For Regional Bank Corporation, with a beta of zero point nine, the required return is nine point nine percent—lower than CloudTech's but still reflective of exposure to credit and interest-rate cycles. Finally, for GreenEnergy Utilities, whose beta is only zero point five, the required return is seven point five percent, indicating that investors view it as a safe and stable investment relative to the overall market. I also constructed a Security Market Line visualization, which plots expected returns against beta values. The graph showed a clear, upward-sloping linear relationship: as beta increases, so does the required rate of return. This confirmed that the CAPM behaves as expected in quantifying the trade-off between risk and return. The Validate stage focused on verifying that the model's results made logical and economic sense. Indeed, the relationship between beta and expected return followed the theoretical pattern—higher beta corresponds to higher required return. To deepen the analysis, I explored the industry context behind each company's beta value. CloudTech's high beta can be explained by its dependence on investor sentiment and its exposure to innovation risk and revenue volatility. Startups in the software sector often have unpredictable earnings and rely heavily on market optimism to attract funding. Regional Bank's beta, at zero point nine, reflects its moderate exposure to economic cycles. Banks tend to perform well in periods of stable growth but are vulnerable to credit risk and interest-rate fluctuations. Finally, GreenEnergy's low beta reflects the stable, regulated nature of the utilities industry. Because utilities provide essential services, their demand remains steady even during economic downturns, resulting in lower systematic risk. In the Evaluate stage, I conducted scenario and sensitivity analyses to understand how changing macroeconomic conditions affect the required rate of return. In a recession scenario, where the market risk premium increases from six percent to eight percent due to heightened risk aversion, all three companies experience a rise in their cost of equity. CloudTech's required return jumps from fifteen point three to eighteen point nine percent, Regional Bank's increases to eleven point seven percent, and GreenEnergy's rises slightly to eight point five percent. This shows that during downturns, investors demand higher compensation for risk, and high-beta companies suffer the most. In contrast, under a recovery scenario where interest rates fall to three percent and the market risk premium narrows to five percent, the cost of equity declines across the board. CloudTech's required return drops to twelve percent, Regional Bank's to seven point five percent, and GreenEnergy's to five point five percent. These results show that monetary easing and improving market sentiment can significantly lower funding costs, particularly for riskier growth companies. After completing the scenario analysis, I proposed a set of strategic recommendations for CloudTech to manage and reduce its cost of capital. The company should first focus on revenue stability by expanding recurring SaaS subscriptions and securing long-term contracts. It should also maintain capital structure discipline by avoiding excessive leverage and prioritizing retained earnings or long-term equity financing. Transparency in investor communication is crucial—accurate forecasts and consistent reporting can build investor confidence and lower perceived risk. In addition, CloudTech should diversify its partnerships to reduce customer concentration and dependence on any single source of revenue. Finally, operational hedging—such as protecting against interest rate or currency fluctuations—can further stabilize the firm's cash flows and investor outlook. After implementing and evaluating the CAPM, I compared it with several alternative valuation models. The CAPM remains one of the most widely used methods for estimating the cost of equity because of its simplicity and clear theoretical foundation. However, it has limitations. The Dividend Discount Model, or DDM, estimates the cost of equity as the sum of the dividend yield and the expected growth rate of dividends. It can be very accurate for stable, dividend-paying firms, but it is not applicable to growth-stage companies like CloudTech that reinvest profits rather than distribute them. The Fama–French three-factor model expands on CAPM by including size and value factors, providing a better fit for explaining returns across different types of firms, although it requires more data. The Arbitrage Pricing Theory, or APT, incorporates multiple macroeconomic factors and is more flexible, but it is complex and less practical for straightforward corporate analysis. Reflecting on this, CAPM remains practical for early-stage and general valuation work, but it should ideally be cross-validated with multi-factor or dividend-based models when data allows. The key is to balance simplicity with realism. In the final Reflect stage, I critically assessed the limitations of the CAPM model. One limitation is that it assumes a static beta, while in reality, a company's risk profile changes over time with leverage, growth, and market conditions. CAPM is also a single-factor model—it ignores other sources of risk such as size, value, or momentum effects. Moreover, it assumes rational and efficient markets, which do not always exist. Investor psychology and behavioral biases can distort equilibrium pricing. Finally, the model's reliance on domestic risk-free rates makes it less effective in international or inflation-divergent contexts. Despite these limitations, CAPM remains a valuable framework because it quantifies the relationship between risk and return in a consistent, transparent way. For venture capital contexts, strategic cost of capital management—achieved through operational stability, diversification, and investor trust—is just as critical as mathematical precision. To conclude, this project demonstrates how the CAPM can serve as both a theoretical and practical tool for investment decision-making. By systematically applying the DRIVER framework—Define, Represent, Implement, Validate, Evaluate, and Reflect—I was able to build a complete analysis process from identifying the business question to interpreting the final financial implications. The results highlight that high-growth companies like CloudTech face higher required returns due to their risk exposure, while stable industries such as utilities enjoy lower costs of capital. Changes in the macroeconomic environment, especially in interest rates and market risk premiums, can dramatically shift these required returns. Ultimately, CAPM provides a disciplined way to link market behavior to company-level decision-making. Understanding and managing that relationship is essential for sustaining competitiveness and long-term financial resilience. Thank you.

Answer: Hi, I'm Damian Lopez and this is my Session 7 assignment. The scenario we're given is to determine the cost of equity for three companies with varying risk profiles using the capital asset pricing model. Video Assignment Submission Process
STEP 1: Record Your Video

Use ANY recording software: Zoom, Teams, OBS, or built-in screen recorder
Show your screen AND your face 
Walk through your financial analysis step-by-step
Show real understanding

STEP 2: Upload to YouTube

Upload to your YouTube account
Set visibility to "Public" or "Unlisted" (NOT Private)
Enable automatic captions/transcripts (YouTube will generate these)
Copy the full YouTube URL

STEP 3: Submit on Brightspace

Paste YouTube link in the submission area

STEP 4: Verify Access

Test your links in an incognito browser window
If you can't view it, neither can I = automatic zero
Key point: I just need to be able to watch it - Public or Unlisted both work

Submit your transcript pure text. This must be the exact transcript from your YouTube video with transcripts turned on. 

Copy and paste your video transcript directly in the text box (from YouTube's auto-generated captions or your own transcript - DO NOT attach files)

Dr. Z’s textbook: https://cinderzhang.github.io. 
Complete the work as outlined. 

Submit ONLY your YouTube video link for this session assignment. Requirements: (1) No video file uploads - link only; (2) Video must be viewable by instructor (set as unlisted if you don't want it public); (3) Must have transcripts turned on; (4) Follow assignment instructions.

Video Assignment Submission Process
STEP 1: Record Your Video

Use ANY recording software: Zoom, Teams, OBS, or built-in screen recorder
Show your screen AND your face 
Walk through your financial analysis step-by-step
Show real understanding

STEP 2: Upload to YouTube

Upload to your YouTube account
Set visibility to "Public" or "Unlisted" (NOT Private)
Enable automatic captions/transcripts (YouTube will generate these)
Copy the full YouTube URL

STEP 3: Submit on Brightspace

Paste YouTube link in the submission area

STEP 4: Verify Access

Test your links in an incognito browser window
If you can't view it, neither can I = automatic zero
Key point: I just need to be able to watch it - Public or Unlisted both work

Submit your transcript pure text. This must be the exact transcript from your YouTube video with transcripts turned on. 

Copy and paste your video transcript directly in the text box (from YouTube's auto-generated captions or your own transcript - DO NOT attach files)
