Answer: Hi everybody, my name is Jacob and today we're going to be going through my session 7 weekly video assignment which covers the cost of equity as well as the capital assets pricing model. As always, obviously we're going to be using the driver framework to strengthen and to form our analysis and in order to solve the problem. So let's get straight into it. Starting with the discover stage of this analysis where we're really just going to understand what is our problem, what is the question we're going to be solving and how we're going to go about solving this problem. So really the core question of this model is how do three distinct business models company A of cloud tech, company B a regional bank corporation and then green energy utilities help use their risk and combine that with cost of capital in the changing environments to help showcase return. So company A, Cloudtech, has a beta of 1.8. They are 100% equity finance which is something important that we'll get into in just a second. Company B is the regional bank corp. They have a beta of about 0.9. They're a traditional banking operation. And then green energy utilities has a beta of 0.5. We get a few other market parameters right here. The risk-free rate is 4 1.5%. The market risk premium 6% and then the expected S&P 500 return is about 10 12%. So let's come all the way down here to this main define and discover stage. And really what are we trying to do? We're trying to figure out what's the best investment decision to make in terms of risk profile. So, how does risk impact the decision-m that you can make? So, we're going to determine the minimum rate of returns, which is the cost of equity for these three companies using the CAPM, allowing the firms to set appropriate investment hurdle hurdles, and then finally develop a strategic plan for cloud tech to help reduce their high costs of capitals and remain competitive in the rising interest rate environment. Um, obviously, we're going to be facing constraints within this situation. We're only going to be using the CAPM, which we're going to use through Python. As well, we're constrained by the current high interest rate market. The risk-free rate is locked at 4 and a.5%. And the market risk premium is about 6%. And then as well, we have our betas right here, 1.8, 0.9, and then 0.5. So, pretty much what is beta? Because before we get into the problem, we want to know a little bit about what it is. Beta is simply a measure of a stock's systematic risk, which is the risk that can't be eliminated through diversification. So it simply quantifies how a company's stock price is changing in the overall market. So a beta of exactly 1.0 is the market average. So it moves exactly in line with how the market changes in the S&P 500 which is about 10 a.5%. A beta above one, which we can see from cloud tech, which is our software startup, means that that stock is much more valuable than the market, which means that if the market raises 10%, the stock's expected to rise 18%. But if the stock if the S&P drops by 10%, then that stock's going to drop by 18%. And then a lower beta of less than one means that it's less volatile means that your returns are going to be less, but your risk overall is a lot lower. And we're going to simply just consider all of these before we get into it. We're going to use the S&P 500 rate when we are going into our project so we understand what we're going into. The next stage of the driver framework is the represent stage where we're really going to look at how are we going to be solving this problem today. So I built out a flowchart right over here as well as the CPM analytical function down at the bottom. We'll start with that. That function right there helps us to calculate the cost of equity. It's the risk-free rate plus beta times the market rate premium or market risk premium. We're going to use that throughout this situation to be able to understand the risk associated with each of these stocks and each of these companies to figure out which makes the most sense. And then looking at this flowchart right here, how are we going to be solving the problem? So, we're going to start obviously we're in our define and discover phases and then our represent stage. Then we're going to get into the implementation. We're going to start by actually plotting the data. We're going to look at the data um plotting it with a security market line to analyze that risk versus return. And then we're going to look at the beta differences, how those are impacted, and then a sanity check to really figure out if our data matches up with the S&P 500, and then look at a strategic plan for cloud tech. Is this something that could be beneficial to help make them maybe a little bit less volatile? And then also model a recession scenario. So maybe if the government or if the economy doesn't turn out as well as we think it could. And then we're going to end it off by reflecting. And we're going to go through a full assessment of the limitations of this model and then also determine and talk about some additional models and additional valuation methods that we can use to help make this problem successful. So now with all of that out of the way, let's get directly right into the implementation side of things. Let's get right into phase one into our Python code. So we're going to pull it right over here. So, the first thing I wanted to do obviously is to import all of the necessary data analysis features and the graphing calculations that we're going to be needing. And then when you scroll down right here, it puts all of that stuff in there. And then let's get right down to the main block right over here. We're going to jump right into our implementation stage. So when running that CAPM with our market parameters, a high risk-free rate of 4 and a.5% and a market risk premium of 6%, we established the following minimum required returns right over here. So you have your cost of beta right here. And then you have your basic return percentage right here. So for cloud tech, it's 15.3%, right here, it's 9.9% and then green energy is 7.5%. That makes sense. The higher the beta, the higher return is going to be required since cloud tech is the most volatile. It's also the most risky, which means that you need a higher return rate in order for it to make the most sense. Right here, right in the middle of that regional bank at about 9.9%. It's very similar to that expected um S&P 500 rate of about 10 12% because that beta, as we said earlier, is very, very close to one. And then this one's a little bit lower because it is a little bit more stable. there's going to be more predictable cash flows. So, in times of economic downturn or in times where you don't really know what the economy is going to do, green energy right here does actually make the most sense. And I wanted to graph this. I wanted to visualize these results. So, we used a security market line in order to do so. So, this pretty much is a graphical representation of these values. Beta is going to be on the x axis and then that required return rate is going to be on the y-axis. The slope right over here, this line that you see, that security market line is our market risk premium, which is 6%, that's simply the market's current compensation for taking on risk. It starts right here, 4.5%, and then goes all the way up into the future right here. You can see all the companies plotted right here, A and then B and then C. Cloud Tech all the way over here on the right shows that it is very, very risky, but it also provides a pretty high return, but it is on that line, which is a thing that we can look at positively. And then green energy all the way down at the bottom on the left shows it is very minimally risky, but the return is also a lot lower. So really this shows that in general all of these three companies are priced pretty low. They're right on that security market line. So while they might not have that exact market rate of 10 12%. They have the expected return but also that risk associated it so that it balances everything else like that. So now we're going to move a little bit more into more implementation. We plugged in a lot of the code to show a lot of the math and then we're going to look a little bit at risk and everything that goes into risk associated with this. This is more on the validation side of things. So we're just going to start with a simple beta analysis. You see your beta originally is one. Your one is the way the market changes. So if let's say the S&P 500 is what you're using, that's going to be one right here. Cloud tech is at 1.8. eight. That means that it's going to be a lot more volatile than the market is. And then your regional bank is very similar. It trends normally with the market. And then green energy all the way down over here. Cloud tech is going to be extremely systematically risky simply due to the high operating leverage. It has it's a startup so it's going to have high research and development costs and everything like that. And as well since it's completely funded by stockholders, completely funded by equity, you really don't know what's going on in regards to it. The next thing that we wanted to do with that validation side of things is really understand if the data that we got, if those percentages, if those numbers that we got actually make sense in the real world. And that's always a very interesting side of things because when you are doing problems and you are working through things, you want to make sure that the numbers that you're using actually do make some complete sense. So, we completed a sanity check as it's called against the S&P 500 market benchmark rate, which is about 10.5%. So, you can see that's going to be a number right over here. And then our validation does confirm that all three of these results pass. Cloud tech at 15.3% passes because that high risk, that beta of 1.8 demands that return above the 10.5% market benchmark and it does. It's 15.3%. The regional bank is right in the middle. It passes because it has that beta very close and as well that percentage is also very close to that 10 and a half%. And then green energy at the bottom. That beta is going to be very very low. Meaning that it is very minimally risky but that return is going to be less than that S&P 500 rate. It's only 7 12% but it passes that test. It makes sense and we can use that disaster shown right over here in this chart. You can see the S&P 500 rate at 10 and a half%. The cloudtech one's going to be a lot higher, which makes sense because it is more risky. The green energy ones over on the right, it is less risky, so it's going to be lower down there. So, that is all we have for the validation side of things. Let's move a little bit into the evolve stage. We're going to look at some actual strategies that we can use to help align with this risk and maybe plan for it. So, in situations that the risk might not be beneficial, we can use it strongly. So, we're going to start right down here at the bottom with cost and capital management strategies because cloud tech faces that rate of 15.3% in order for it to make sense as an investment. The market is sensitive. You don't fully know exactly what's going on with the market. So, our strategy for cloud tech is how can we help to reduce that systematic risk? How can we get that beta below that 1.8 um 1.8 value? So our recommendation, the first one is just to leverage it. So maybe to introduce a small manageable amount of debt into the 100% equity capital structure just to help balance out where that money specifically is coming from as well reducing that risk. to attacking that driver and stabilize revenue by maybe pushing clients toward more multi-year non-cancable contract lockins because that makes sure that even in longer situations where maybe contracts aren't coming in, you still have contracts on the books that you know you're going to get revenue and you're going to get money for. And then also just communicate with your investors. Be proactive with everything that's going on. Emphasize those high revenue retention rates and be predictable with your cash flows. You want to know where your money is coming from so that when you're going to investors with everything like that, it makes sense and you can understand it. And then the other stage of the evolves, the other step of the evolve stage, it's actually a little bit on the other side and that is looking at situations where the code or where the market might not perform as normal. And for this, we looked at a recession. So in the base case that return is going to be 4.5% that market rate is going to be 6%. But let's say in a recession where the economy is not doing well, your returns aren't going to be high. Your rate is going to be 3% and then your market rate that you need is going to be 7 and a half% because people are less willing and less able to put money into the market because they're worried that their money will not perform well. You can actually see right here the required return goes up under a recession scenario for cloud tech because you don't know what's going on. It is even more risky in this situation because you don't know what's fully going on. And that's an important thing to look at. The high beta right over here amplifies the market fear that the required return increases by about 1.2 percentage points during that downturn. It's extremely vulnerable. Um so we always need to look at it when we are looking at it. But on the other side actually green energy which is AC has that low beta which we've talked about a lot and that helps to minimize the effect and the fear of the risk associated with that stock. So the drop in that rate the drop in the risk-free rate causes the required return to actually fall by 75 percentage points. And you can see that right over here on this graph it drops just a little bit because it's a defensive asset. You invest money into it and you know you might not make the most money but you are comfortable and you are stable. So no matter what happens in this situation, you are going to be okay in the long run. And now tying this all together, what does this mean? How can we actually implement and how can we actually understand what we've talked about? And the biggest thing to understand is the limitations that are associated with this model. So while CAPM is the necessary starting point, it is the model that we're using through this analysis, it does have flaws. It is never perfect. And that's what this chart right here outputs. The biggest problem specifically is that's a single factor model. It only assumes that beta is the only compensated risk associated. It ignores factors like maybe the size of the firm and the value associated with it which actually drive returns in the real market. Obviously we talked about the first firm being a startup being a smaller firm 100% equity financed. But look at it in the real life example. Maybe a company like Apple. Apple, while they might make some rash decisions, while they might do things that maybe upset some shareholders and don't make everybody happy, they're such a large company that even making those super rash decisions won't actually have an impact on their actual cap, on their actual company because they are so large. So, the risk associated with Apple, yes, they might go up, yes, they might go down, is a lot less than a smaller company would be. as well. The model relies heavily on unre unreliable estimates for inputs like the forward-looking market risk premium and it assumes perfect markets which never actually exist in reality. We talked about a recession in the evolved stage. We never know what's going to happen with the market and that's something that's really interesting to look at. So we really have to understand and know that this might not always be perfect and this is just an example and we can use it to analyze it and to build analysis and build data but we can't actually pinpoint exactly. And then also you can look at an alternative model to help mitigate weaknesses. Maybe just pulling in a different model. We're going to use the DDM, the dividend discount model, which we talked about in earlier sessions of this class to kind of help balance everything out and understand is the intrinsic value of the stock. Is this investment something that makes sense? And you can see it actually comes out to align pretty well with it. Also, it uses those perfect market relationships and those translations. But overall, this project really confirms that while the CAPM provides the essential foundation for setting it, we have to integrate scenario modeling. we have to look at multimodel valuations in order to understand completely what's going on and also to completely solve our problem. So this really ties everything that we've talked about together. We covered a lot of the math behind everything, but we also just looked at the strategic plans for cloud tech. We kind of looked and understood how does the CAPM, how does that capital asset pricing model actually really make an impact in decision-m in terms of risk and everything like that. We used the driver framework to structure this analysis. So we walked through define, discover, represent, implement, validate, evolve, and then reflecting on everything at the end. I hope I answered all the questions that were asked, and yeah, that's all I have. Thank you.
